channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 23
item.description: (NYT)  Read: There's a name for the blah you're feeling: languishing.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tesla Struggles with More Upsets in China This Week
item.description: But the company's cavalier attitude and inability to keep up with auto repairs as sales grow rapidly have rubbed some Chinese regulators the wrong way. In March, Tesla cars were banned from military complexes in China over fears their cameras would be used to spy on the government.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Supreme Court Limits FTC's Ability to Recoup Ill-Gotten Gains
item.description: Justices said the FTC needs to ask Congress to grant those powers back, which acting FTC Chair Rebecca Slaughter did earlier this week.  For decades, the FTC has used a provision called Section 13(b) to recoup billions of dollars and (at times) pay back consumers.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Biden Will Propose Nearly Doubling Capital Gains Tax
item.description: President Biden will soon propose nearly doubling the capital gains tax for wealthy people to 39.6%, according to Bloomberg.  To pay for the first plan, which includes spending on bridges and broadband, Biden wants to hike taxes on corporations. Critics of the current capital gains system say, "So you're telling me this rich investor is paying less in taxes on their stock sales than a middle-class worker pays on their income? To pay for his second proposal, which includes spending on childcare and paid leave for workers, he wants to hike taxes on wealthy investors.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: April 23
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Tesla Struggles with More Upsets in China This Week
item.description: But the company's cavalier attitude and inability to keep up with auto repairs as sales grow rapidly have rubbed some Chinese regulators the wrong way. item.description: Justices said the FTC needs to ask Congress to grant those powers back, which acting FTC Chair Rebecca Slaughter did earlier this week.  For decades, the FTC has used a provision called Section 13(b) to recoup billions of dollars and (at times) pay back consumers.

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 23
item.description: Stat: 2.8 million people in the US subscribed to HBO Max in Q1; Netflix added just 450,000 subs across the US and Canada in the same period. (NYT)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Will Propose Nearly Doubling Capital Gains Tax
item.description: President Biden will soon propose nearly doubling the capital gains tax for wealthy people to 39.6%, according to Bloomberg.  To pay for the first plan, which includes spending on bridges and broadband, Biden wants to hike taxes on corporations. Critics of the current capital gains system say, "So you're telling me this rich investor is paying less in taxes on their stock sales than a middle-class worker pays on her income? To pay for his second proposal, which includes spending on childcare and paid leave for workers, he wants to hike taxes on wealthy investors.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NFTs, Intellectual Property, and What It Really Means to Own a Digital Kitty
item.description: Bluebox is a new NFT platform that automatically copyrights an artist’s song and then divides that into 100 NFTs that include 1% of the song’s copyright. Some platforms set terms for buyers’ intellectual property rights because the platforms themselves create and mint the NFTs. But on platforms like OpenSea and Nifty Gateway, where creators can mint NFTs of their own works…Artists aren’t so willing to give away their IP Giphy Surprise, surprise: There were no copyrights attached to the sales of multimillion-dollar music NFTs by 3LAU, Steve Aoki, Kings of Leon, and Grimes. And Linkin Park’s Mike Shinoda, who released a new song as an NFT in April, told Input magazine, “There’s nobody who’s serious about NFTs who really humors the idea that what you’re selling is the copyright or the master.”  An NFT without the copyright is like one of the purses, not Mickey Mouse himself.  For creators like Shinoda, that’s because selling the copyrights to his work would mean ceding all future profits that work could generate. An NFT can include IP, but it doesn’t have to.  Copyright permissions for NFTs can be set by the “minter” (the person who turns a creative asset into an NFT), or they can be set by “walled garden” platforms that do all the minting themselves. Whether the works of art represented by these blockchain-backed digital tokens are protected by copyright law. Picture this: NFTs and intellectual property (IP) are like the opposite sides of a Venn diagram. A copyright allows its owner to use a work in whichever way they choose, and to profit off of its use. The case gets more complicated than that, but it’s significant here because it's the first high-profile intellectual property squabble in the NFT space.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: In Pictures: Australia and New Zealand Open Travel Bubble
item.description: Morgan and Jenny Evans via Getty Images   James D. dang allergies are so bad this spring ... sorry ...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Microsoft Study Shows Need for Breaks in Between Video Meetings
item.description: Back-to-back meetings without breaks cause a measurable buildup in the brain of stress-related beta waves, according to a new study from Microsoft's Human Factors Lab. Even short breaks can help the brain "reset" and improve focus during meetings.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 22
item.description: (John Burn-Murdoch) Read: A deep dive into the situation. —Ramanan Laxminarayan, director of New Delhi’s Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics, and Policy to CNN.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: President Biden Holds Virtual Climate Summit With 40 World Leaders
item.description: Leaders are expected to announce their own commitments that match, exceed, or Wizard Chess-counter Biden’s proposal.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Amazon Announces New Salon, Furniture Assembly Service, and Palm-Reading Payment
item.description: Amazon is reportedly planning to launch a new furniture assembly service to try and one-up Wayfair and loosen its grip on the housewares retail space. Now, its new contactless payment method will expand from Amazon Go and Amazon Books stores to seven Whole Foods locations in the Seattle area. Use your palm to pay.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden Administration Confronts Less Demand for Vaccines
item.description: According to a new report from the Kaiser Family Foundation, in just a few weeks the US will reach a “tipping point” on vaccine enthusiasm where the supply of doses will exceed the number of people who want to get jabbed.  Some experts think that vaccine hesitancy levels are so high that the US will never fully achieve herd immunity against Covid-19. Former FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb estimates that only 150 million Americans (less than half the population) will get a vaccine.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 22
item.description: (John Burn-Murdoch) Read: A deep dive into the situation. —Ramanan Laxminarayan, director of New Delhi’s Center for Disease Dynamics, Economics, and Policy to CNN.

Former FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb estimates that only 150 million Americans (less than half the population) will get a vaccine.  Some experts think that vaccine hesitancy levels are so high that the US will never fully achieve herd immunity against the coronavirus.

item.title: Microsoft Study Shows Need for Breaks in Between Video Meetings
item.description: Back-to-back meetings without breaks cause a measurable buildup in the brain of beta waves, which are associated with stress, according to a new study from Microsoft's Human Factors Lab. Even short breaks can help the brain "reset" and improve focus during meetings.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Reader Q&A: The Difference Between SPACs, IPOs, and Direct Listings
item.description: The details can get hard to remember, so take this explainer and bookmark it. At a high level…IPOs are a 6–12 month journey where a company works with investment banks and underwriters, who buy a bunch of shares and then sell them to investors in the public market during the actual IPO.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 21
item.description: Black people account for 6.8% of Goldman's total US workforce. (Slate) Read: Really though, what jeans are in style now?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NYT Analysis Shows Migration Patterns Pre-Pandemic Stayed Mostly the Same
item.description: According to the NYT's Upshot, which analyzed 30 million change-of-address requests in 2020, "Migration patterns during the pandemic have looked a lot like migration patterns before it."  Bottom line: This analysis highlights the stickiness of pre-pandemic migration patterns."
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Apple Announces Devices with Custom M1 Chips at Special Event
item.description: Apple Card features for families, including shared credit lines Podcast subscriptions, in a swipe at SpotifyUpdated Apple TV box with a new remote and, most importantly, a trailer for Ted Lasso season 2Investors weren't blown away, and shares fell about 2% after the event.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Super League In Doubt After Manchester City Backs Out
item.description: All six English Premier League clubs that had initially signed onto the Super League, including Manchester City and Liverpool, said they're backing out yesterday after feeling the heat from supporters.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Netflix Announces Disappointing Streamer Growth in 2021
item.description: Netflix remains the majority of viewers’ No. 1 choice of stream-and-chill service, and up to 92% of viewers that signed up for competing streaming services also have Netflix. Netflix predicted that in Q2 only 1 million net new subscribers will join the service—that would make it the worst quarter for subscriber growth on record. Of course, last year was special: In prime position to benefit from pandemic lockdowns, Netflix managed to increase its subscriber base to 204 million and bump up the price on its standard streaming plan by $1 and its premium tier by $2. Looking ahead... 2.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Reader Q&A: The Difference Between SPACs, IPOs, and Direct Listings
item.description: At a high level…IPOs are a 6–12 month journey where a company works with investment banks and underwriters, who buy a bunch of shares and then sell them to investors in the public market during the actual IPO. Question from too many of you to count: What's the difference between an IPO, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), and a direct listing?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Microsoft Researchers Measure Stress of Back-to-Back Meetings
item.description: Back-to-back meetings without breaks cause a measurable buildup in the brain of beta waves, which are associated with stress, according to a new study from Microsoft's Human Factors Lab. Even short breaks can help the brain "reset" and improve focus during meetings.

item.title: The Ingenuity Helicopter's Flight Called a 'Wright Brothers Moment'
item.description: Ingenuity had to fly completely on its own with no direct contact from its handling team on Earth. But first, a few more test flights over the next two weeks.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 20
item.description: (New Yorker)  Read: Hollywood mega-agent Ari Emanuel's second act. The legal battle over the future of European fútbol has begun.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: McDonald's Announces BTS Meal as Next Collab in Famous Orders Program
item.description: McDonald's announced a new partnership with Grammy-nominated K-pop sensations BTS as part of its Famous Orders program. The Korean boyband has 34.5 million Twitter followers, 31.8 million TikTok followers, and was the top-selling act of 2020 globally, beating out artists like Taylor Swift and Drake.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Facebook Reveals Its Big Push Into Audio
item.description: New features include rooms for hosting live audio discussions, a feed of short audio clips similar to Instagram's Reels, and tools for podcasters."
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Pew: 91% of US Adults Now Support Legalized Marijuana in Some Form
item.description: Canada legalized recreational cannabis in 2018, and Mexico could follow soon. Legalization can bring big economic opportunity: The US marijuana industry already supports 300,000+ full-time jobs—more than the number of dentists in the country. Bottom line: "Legalization will eventually win, and the vast majority of states, if not all, will soon join the ranks of the legalizers," Vox writes.  In their latest survey, Pew found that 60% of US adults now support legalized recreational and medical use and an additional 31% back medical marijuana. And a lack of federal standards has led to inconsistency around testing, labeling, and marketing.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Facebook Reveals Its Big Push Into Audio
item.description: New features include rooms for hosting live audio discussions, a feed of short audio clips similar to Instagram's Reels, and tools for podcasters."
